body.plain:
Coheed and Cambria is an American rock band from Nyack, NY, whose music is often labeled as progressive rock or new prog. The band’s first seven albums (as well as their ninth and tenth) correspond with the nonlinear story of The Amory Wars, an intergalactic science-fiction epic created by frontman Claudio Sanchez. A simplified version of the story can be found here.

An early variant of the band formed in 1995 under the name Beautiful Loser, and was quickly renamed to the more well-known former band name Shabutie. After a few changes to the lineup and three EPs along the way, Coheed and Cambria formed, consisting of Sanchez (vocals, guitar), Travis Stever (guitar, backing vocals), Michael Todd (bass, backing vocals) and Josh Eppard (drums, backing vocals).

The group released their debut studio album, The Second Stage Turbine Blade, in March of 2002 after signing with Equal Vision Records. Their follow-up, In Keeping Secrets of Silent Earth: 3, hit stores October of the following year and was RIAA-certified gold, with its leading single “A Favor House Atlantic.” Switching to Columbia Records, Coheed released the first volume of Good Apollo, I’m Burning Star IV (From Fear Through the Eyes of Madness) in September of 2005. The album was also certified gold and boasted the band’s arguably most well-known song “Welcome Home.”

November of 2006 was a dark time for the band, as it brought the departure of Eppard and Todd for personal, drug-related issues. After five months of playing with temporary fill-ins, Todd rejoined and the band recruited drummer Chris Pennie, formerly of The Dillinger Escape Plan. The second volume of Good Apollo (No World For Tomorrow) was released in October of 2007, but due to contractual reasons surrounding Pennie, Foo Fighters drummer Taylor Hawkins played drums on the album. One member shy of the “original” lineup, the band played a small string of four-night concert events in U.S. and U.K.— termed Neverender—chronologically corresponding to their four existing albums in late 2008. The band’s fifth album, Year of the Black Rainbow, was released in April of 2010, acting as a prequel to the storyline of their previous albums. While touring in the summer of 2011, Todd was arrested on charges of armed robbery, with Pennie leaving later that year, allowing Eppard to reclaim his role as the drummer.

A year after losing Todd, the band picked up former AM to PM bassist Zach Cooper. Between October of 2012 and February of 2013, the band released their sixth and seventh albums as a double album titled The Afterman in two installments —Ascension and Descension respectively—under Hundred Handed/Everything Evil Records. After another label change to 300 Entertainment, the group’s eighth studio album, The Color Before the Sun, would mark the band’s first non-conceptual release, instead reflecting on recent changes in Sanchez’s life. It peaked at #10 on the Billboard 200 and was their first album to see a #1 spot on a Billboard chart, under Top US Rock Albums.

In May of 2018, the band’s social media accounts began teasing new music with images and quotes seemingly related to The Amory Wars. Releasing “The Dark Sentencer” a few weeks later, Coheed confirmed their album Vaxis – Act I: The Unheavenly Creatures—along with the subsequent albums in the Vaxis series—will be revisiting the Amory Wars saga with new characters and stories, also marking the band’s return to conceptual album writing. Act I: The Unheavenly Creatures released on October 5.

description.plain:
“Welcome Home” details the dark, vindictive vision had by the story’s god character, The Writer, in which he gets revenge on Erica Court, the woman who cheated on him and derailed his life, by burying her alive. It is one of the band’s most popular singles, helped by its presence in various media such as the video games Rock Band and Madden NFL 06, as well as the trailers for the movie 9.

Written by vocalist/guitarist Claudio Sanchez, it is the third track on Coheed and Cambria’s 2005 concept album, Good Apollo, I’m Burning Star IV, Volume One: From Fear Through the Eyes of Madness, and the lead single from the album.

description.plain:
“The Dark Sentencer” is a space-rock song about the prison-planet of the same name, in which the two main characters try to escape from, in the storyline on The Unheavenly Creatures.

The song is the first single on the album and was originally released on May 29th, 2018 on Coheed and Cambria’s YouTube channel.

description.plain:
The second single from the album, it recounts and introduces the relationship of Creature and Sister Spider, and what had transpired between them.

Taking place before the events on The Dark Sentencer, it recounts the last major event that happened between Nostrand (Creature), Nia (Sister Spider), and Otto (Colossus).

description.plain:
The Suffering is a single from progressive rock band Coheed and Cambria’s album ‘Good Apollo.. Volume 1…’.

This song seems to be mostly an exchange between Ryder and Erica Court, as she leaves Ryder after he confuses her with a fictional character from his story during sex. It’s hard to say that the song only has one speaker, as there appear to be lines from both characters.

songs.lyrics:
A broad incision sits across the evening
The victim to our fathers' lost war

Will they be buried here, among the dead
In the silent secret?

The pioneers
In dealing with if they march for dawn
Of Will and worthy
The truth be told, the child was born

Man your own jackhammer!
Man your battle stations
We'll have you dead, pretty soon
And now
Sincerely written
From my brother's blood machine to yours
Man your battle stations
We'll have you home, pretty soon
And now

Awake through motion
With curiosity to curtain your first move
Over arms length, they'll break protocol
Jealous envy for the youngest one
To be the hero is all I'll ask
Can I be buried here, among the dead
With room to honor me here in the end?
You'll be better off too soon

The pioneers

Man your own jackhammer!

Sincerely written

Man your battle stations
We'll have you home, pretty soon
And now

For you, I'd do anything just to make you happy
Hear you tell me that you're proud of me
For them, I'll kill anything
Cut the throats of babies for them
Break their hearts, for they were there
Waiting for you to say "I love you, too"
The navigator, the pilot, her favorite
The one they call the Vision that bears the gift
The navigator, the pilot, her favorite
The one they call the Vision that bears the gift

Will, do the children really understand
The things you did to them?
And why, oh why, should they conjure up the will?
For you, my love, I would kill him
We're coming home pretty soon
Coming home

Should the irony grow hungry

We were one among the fence

Now, we're coming home
Man your own jackhammer!
Man your battle stations
We'll have you dead, pretty soon
And now
Sincerely written
From my brother's blood machine to yours
Man your battle stations
We'll have you home, pretty soon
Tonight...

description.plain: “The Gutter” deals with the primary conflict between Nostand and Nia: her being left for dead in the bank vault and seemingly abandoned by Nostand, after Otto’s betrayal. The title refers to the special “belt” implanted in Dark Sentencer denizens upon arrival, which acts as both tracker and assurance that they won’t do anything stupid, as it is capable of literally “gutting” them, boring through their vital organs.

description.plain:
“You’ve Got Spirit, Kid” was the first single (released on July 10th, 2015) from Coheed and Cambria’s forthcoming eighth album The Color Before The Sun, which was released on October 16, 2015.  A lyric video of the song was published on youtube.com on July 7th.

The album is the band’s first non-concept album, with all previous ones taking place in the band’s fictional universe abased around the storyline of The Amory Wars

I kind of want people to know that Coheed can write that sort of record.  I’ve always said in the past that there’s never been a limitation on the band. It makes no sense to me to draw a line in the sand and never cross it
- Claudio Sanchez (vocals; lead guitar)

songs.embed_content: Read “Here to Mars” by Coheed and Cambria on Genius

description.plain:
“This is a love song for my wife, and it allowed me to look at her in a different light. My wife and I collaborate on a ton of things together – a lot of the comic books and the lyrics and music that I write – and now here we were about to collaborate on a life together, and it was just a really special moment that framed her in a way that made me want to express myself in a song for her. So that’s basically what I did, and Here to Mars is me trying to encapsulate that emotion. I wanted the song to feel epic and explosive, and distant like a journey. Some people might get literal with it and say, ‘You only love your wife to Mars? But that’s only the neighbouring planet of our solar system – it’s not really that far away!’ But to me, Mars might as well be the other end of the universe because I’m never going there. Maybe I should just do a series of love songs about the solar system next time out? Ha ha!”


Claudio Sanchez (Team Rock interview)



Link to full article – http://bit.ly/1KduSAg

description.plain:
This song follows the Writing Writer—the fictitious author of The Amory Wars, the story that Coheed and Cambria’s concept albums are built upon—and his mental breakdown in the real world. After having his (ten-speed) bicycle stolen, it reappears to him in a vision as a possessed version of itself—Ten Speed.

Ten Speed tries to convince the Writing Writer that the only way he will find happiness is by killing Ambellina, the love interest of Claudio Kilgannon, in The Amory Wars. The Writer agrees and enters his own story to ensure Ambellina will die.

description.plain:
http://coheedofficial.tumblr.com/post/95747234712/several-months-ago-in-anticipation-of-the-birth

Several months ago, in anticipation of the birth of my son, I wrote “Atlas” for him. At the time, I could only imagine the feelings I’d have for him when I’d have to leave for tour. I didn’t truly understand the power and relevance of the song’s sentiment. Now, after having him in my life for almost three months and with Neverender just a few weeks away, I’m starting to feel it. This will be my first tour away from Atlas. And sure, it will be hard, but it’s all for him. I’d like to share that song with you.


Claudio

songs.embed_content: Read “The Pavilion (A Long Way Back)” by Coheed and Cambria on Genius

description.plain:
Frontman Claudio Sanchez said this of “The Pavilion (A Long Way Back)” in his interview with Rolling Stone:

For example, there was no concept with “Pavilion.” The bare-bones meaning behind that song was basically leaving the band. It wasn’t until I started structuring the actual beats of the story that I found a place for it within the concept. I took those bones and fleshed it out with the backstory of Creature and Sister Spider and how they worked in theater productions. In that second verse, if you listen, it talks about “dressing room carpets” and “broken TVs” — it’s basically the loop of being a band on the road, all the things you sort of endure. For me, it was like, ‘That’s obviously about [leaving the band], but how do I take this real-life situation and feed it to these fictitious characters to give them more legs to stand on, using this song that feels so outside of the concept?”

songs.embed_content: Read “Love Protocol” by Coheed and Cambria on Genius

description.plain:
Guitarist Travis Stever said this of the song in an interview with SCENEzine:


So Claudio had probably written that one a year and a half ago and he showed it to me and lyrically it had what he wanted in it in terms of story line, but it wasn’t quite homed in on quite yet and was undecided about the song. I believe he sent it to Josh and Josh laid some drums down and I remember hearing it and thinking oh man this is a great song and when we were recording the record we weren’t sure it was going to be on the record, it may have just been a bonus but it turned into a very important song.

Conceptually the lyrics were already tied in but I think Claudio felt that it was one of the songs that you create and the put that portion in another place on another song on the record if you know what I mean. So I can say I was very happy when he decided to go forward with the song. Guitar wise a lot of guitar was already there but I added the chorus and some little tid bits here and there, that was one of those kinds of songs where it was pretty flushed out. As a musician you want to add melodies left and right like that is my outlet but its like awh man, well there are plenty of melodies there already, but it was such a great song that I not so much fought for it, as for you could see clearly Claudio was proud of the song but not sure of where it would fit in. In the end, once everybody performed on it, it didn’t take much to say hey man maybe this is a song that should be on the record and everybody was like yeah it should.

So thats Love Protocol’s story from my point of view, I am sure Claudios is very different. Every song is different and Love Protocol for me felt like a song that belonged and it felt like a song that was strong and needed to be heard and thats the sad thing man, if the song had ended up just a bonus track it doesn’t get taken as seriously and I’m glad that song had the chance.

Songs are so very much describing an experience and if you even performed just two notes on a song you are part of the story that’s within that song and that is mine with Love Protocol.

songs.embed_content: Read “Island” by Coheed and Cambria on Genius

description.plain:
“Island is very much the beginning of the record. It opens with the sound of the Q Train going into Brooklyn, and that’s the train that I would frequent when going in and out of Brooklyn into Manhattan. It’s very much the beginning of my identity crisis when writing this record, too. I had a hard time writing songs in this new apartment – or at least I thought I did. And it’s basically a song to my wife, saying that she needed to hear me and understand that it wasn’t working for me. I needed to leave and get back to the country, and that’s essentially what Island is about – just the apartment being too small, and the exposure being too much for me. When I started the song it was all on acoustic, and that was the beginning of this idea of the album being a solo effort. But we transformed it into a rocker, and the guitar at the beginning claws into the idea of distance and landscape, which I really didn’t have being in that apartment. I was longing for space, and the opening guitar line is supposed to resonate that. Then the band comes in, and everything becomes tight and crunchy. Again, that’s meant to be a musical representation of the chaos I was experiencing inside the space of that apartment.” – Claudio Sanchez

Team Rock Interview – http://bit.ly/1KduSAg

songs.embed_content: Read “Devil in Jersey City” by Coheed and Cambria on Genius

description.plain:
“Devil in Jersey City,” in the context of The Amory Wars, is about the attack on Josephine Kilgannon and her fiance, Patrick McCormick, by the gang known as the Jersey City Devils.

The song is the band’s first and only single from their debut album, Second Stage Turbine Blade. The official music video shows the band playing in an abandoned space station that resembles a dragonfly and features scenes incorporating loose aspects of the story, such as implied human experimentation and a couple representing the characters Coheed and Cambria. The man, played by director Christian Winters, has gashes in his arms, indicating the scars left from the blades that extend from Coheed’s arms.

True to the band’s sense of humor, they recorded a second music video for the song in which they’re dressed in farm clothing and playing in a barn, “playing” a guitar, a banjo, trash cans/lids, and a makeshift upright box bass.
